abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is rated
            unsatisfactory. However, sustainability is likely over time,
            due to the continuing Government's efforts to complete
            transactions, and pursue formal, and informal international
            assistance. The key lessons suggest that, while project
            objectives were ambitious, given the political instability,
            the Bank could have adopted monitoring indicators on project
            activities to access a more explicit exit strategy, instead
            of the implicit suspension, and cancellation threats, which
            were in fact used. Therefore, an independent analysis of the
            political environment, in a country where instability risks
            the success of an operation, would be worth considering
            prior to negotiations. The report questions the
            implementation of significant reforms, where hostilities
            hinder not only reform sustainability, but the process of
            privatization itself. It also reveals the risk factor of
            multiple project components, whose main objectives -
            regulatory framework, privatization, and liquidation - did
            not require financial institutions/public sector components
            to support reform, (despite its complementing attributes to
            a macro program); instead, the number of public enterprises
            should have been minimal. However, the participatory process
            demonstrated the local capacity to promote competition, and privatization.
